content.title: The Tower of London, between history, legends and traditions

introduction.small: Facing Tower Bridge on the right bank of the Thames, this medieval fort remains the quintessential testimony of British royalty.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Tower of London, between history, legends and traditions

paragraphs.text:
Discover England's history by exploring the Tower of London. Built in the 1100's, this medieval fortress has been very little modified since the 15th century and is now listed by UNESCO as a World Heritage site. As a symbol of British power, it is still the official palace of the Queen of England - even though the last sovereign who ever lived there was James I, some 400 years ago… Domineering the collective unconscious, from The Musketeers to Sherlock Holmes, the Tower of London holds many legends that you will discover throughout the guided tour. At the centre of the fortress, the 27-metre high keep called the White Tower is linked to more than a few ghost stories: among other things, it was a prison for political prisoners (Elisabeth I was jailed there) and religious nonconformists. Today, it holds the Crown Jewels, the centrepieces of which being the Saint Edward's Crown, set with 444 precious stones, and the Sceptre with Cross. These treasures are heavily guarded by yeomen warders, guards dressed in red and black who are veterans in the British Armed Forces. Do not miss the discreet ceremony of the keys, at exactly seven minutes to 10 p.m. This seven-century-old ritual of about a dozen minutes is suffused with tradition.

Tower of London
St Katharine's & Wapping
London EC3N 4AB

+44 844 482 7777

www.hrp.org.uk/tower-of-london

content.title: 1960's atmosphere at the White City House

introduction.small: Situated in the former BBC head office, the perfect location and singular style of the White City House are the tokens of an unusual London stay.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: 1960's atmosphere at the White City House

paragraphs.text:
Take up residence in this donut-shaped building, a true icon of London's cultural life in the heart of the White City neighbourhood. The former tenant is none other than the BBC, the famous British TV network, which had made it its home office since 1960. Four floors have now been devoted to Soho House's latest hotel. The 1960's-inspired 45 rooms are therefore rearranged offices that will give you an experience suffused with nostalgia. Wander the corridors, where dark vintage striped panelling will take you out to another time. Countless bars and restaurants will be open just for you, on your way to the tower's rooftop, where you will be able to take in the incredible views of the urban landscape, either from the swimming pool, or on a deckchair, book in hand. For an even more relaxing moment, favour certain areas of the hotel where mobile phones and laptops are banned. Log out and enjoy!

White City House
Television Centre
101 Wood Ln
White City
London W12 7FR

+44 20 7870 0000

www.whitecityhouse.com

Rooms: from 100 GBP

content.title: Shangri-La Hotel, panoramic views in the heart of London

introduction.small: The Shard is London's highest building. On its last floors, the British iteration of the Shangri-La offers a dreamlike experience in front of an unobstructed urban landscape.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Shangri-La Hotel, panoramic views in the heart of London

paragraphs.text:
Contrasting with the London sky, the stripped-down, almost futuristic glass stalagmite of the Shangri-La overlooks the City. There, you are guaranteed an incredible view in either of the 202 rooms. Totally in keeping with the oriental elegance of the group is the simple yet sophisticated decoration, using silk and marble materials. Emphasis is being put on the splendid urban landscape that spreads out in front of you through the huge picture windows.
At the crack of dawn, do a few lengths in the famous Shangri-La infinity edge swimming pool located on the 52nd floor, listed as the “highest water tank in Europe”. From up there, you will enjoy incredible vistas over St Paul's Cathedral, the London Eye and Westminster Palace. You surely won't come only to swim though, as the infinity pool is only part of the larger Gŏng lounge bar. As night falls, you can settle in to enjoy – in moderation – cocktails or champagne as you revel in the incredible show of the British capital's sparkling lights.

Shangri-La Hotel
The Shard
31 St Thomas Street
London SE1 9QU

+44 20 7234 8000

www.shangri-la.com/london/shangrila/

Rooms: from 425 GBP

content.title: Ceru, Levantine cuisine in the spotlight

introduction.small: From classic mezze to barbecued meat, enjoy a gustatory journey east, to the Mediterranean but without ever leaving Soho.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Ceru, Levantine cuisine in the spotlight

paragraphs.text:
Several cedars of Lebanon, drawn on the walls, set the tone of the restaurant specialised in Levantine cuisine. At Ceru, two steps away from Oxford Circus in Soho, food is inspired by eastern Mediterranean regions with a modern twist. The menu offers a series of dishes for sharing, from classic mezze to barbecued meat. Comfortably settled in one of the bench seats displaying geometrical patterns and surrounded by colourful Moroccan earthenware, you will keep an eye on the open kitchen as pitas and various Lebanese and Turkish dishes are being prepared. Order a glass of wine from the Eastern Mediterranean area, or a homemade lemonade to wait for your meal. You will then be fully ready to enjoy the hammara, a sour red pepper mash with nuts and pomegranates, the shish taouk, a chicken breast marinated in paprika and lemon served with yogurt sauce, or even the grilled halloumi, a Cypriot cheese. End on a sweet note with a honey and cardamom panna cotta, dressed with rose petals, pomegranate and slivered pistachios.

Ceru
11 D'Arblay Street
London W1F 8DT

+44 20 3195 3002

www.cerurestaurants.com/soho/

Menu: around 13 GBP

content.title: A moment to yourself at the ChromaYoga studio

introduction.small: Make the best of your London stay for a plurisensory fitness session… with yoga under coloured neon lights!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A moment to yourself at the ChromaYoga studio

paragraphs.text:
Based in Shoreditch, the ChromaYoga studio offers a space cut off from the rest of the outside world to practice yoga under neon lights. A new revolutionary approach that combines light and colour therapy techniques, stimulating sonic landscapes and natural scents in order to create an immersive and plurisensory yoga experience. Colours vary according to the level and goal of the attendees. Red is for intense lessons, blue for soft vinyasa (Sanskrit for “breathing tied to one movement”), yellow to regulate the mood, purple for the yin and orange for beginners and pregnant women.
During the lessons, breathing is linked to movements and used to wake up the body as well as raise energy levels. Morning sessions end with a burst of blue light to prepare you for the rest of the day, and nighttime ones with a soft orange one that stimulates a good night sleep. Try it now!

ChromaYoga
45 Charlotte Rd
London EC2A 3DP

+44 20 3488 3219

www.chromayoga.co.uk ﻿

content.title: Henrietta Hotel, between Samuel Scott and Catherine Clive

introduction.small: In the heart of Covent Garden, Henrietta Street hasn't lost its old-world charm, while welcoming many artists and famous publishers.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Henrietta Hotel, between Samuel Scott and Catherine Clive

paragraphs.text:
A cultural and food lovers' meeting point, Henrietta Street has been immersed in the rich history of Covent Garden since 1634. It is on this very street that Jane Austen regularly visited her brother Henry as well as where Victor Gollancz reviewed George Orwell's biography before its publication. Birthplace of literary arts and crafts, Henrietta Street has preserved its Anglo-Dutch blushing brick facades.
Head to numbers 14 and 15 for a lovely night at Hotel Henrietta, in one of the 18 modern, refined and cosy rooms conceived by interior designer Dorothée Meilichzon. Between restaurants, shops and award-winning museums, the hotel is truly a holiday destination, inspired by the surrounding streets. Fabrics, marble, rugs and headboards are handcrafted with utmost care.

Henrietta Hotel
14-15 Henrietta Street
London WC2E 8QH

+44 (0) 20 3794 5313

www.henriettahotel.com

Rooms: from 204 GBP

content.title: Town Hall Hotel, or sleep in a renovated town hall

introduction.small: Set in East End, Town Hall Hotel & Apartments offer a world of contemporary luxury combined with modern touches.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Town Hall Hotel, or sleep in a renovated town hall

paragraphs.text:
The old town hall, completely renovated – without losing its fine figure – now hosts the Town Hall Hotel & Apartments. The 20th century building houses 98 rooms and suites, which perfectly combine original architectural elements and ultra-modern touches. You will appreciate the unostentatious luxury that prevails in the rooms, furnished with modern furniture and transparent partitions that separate bedrooms from bathrooms.
At the end of the day, the indoor pool is the perfect place to relax and leave behind all your worries. Illuminated by the daylight from the ceiling, mosaic reflections change colours according to the hour. In the evening, the Typing Room and Corner Room restaurants will delight you with refined European cuisine.

Town Hall Hotel
Patriot Square
London E2 9NF

+44 (0)20 7871 0460

www.townhallhotel.com

content.title: Brixton Village, gourmet face of London

introduction.small: Passing through bustling London, the Brixton district offers a thriving gastronomic culture that permanently attracts food lovers.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Brixton Village, gourmet face of London

paragraphs.text:
Why not pop over to the heart of the Caribbean? For several years, the former British colonies have been invited to Brixton Village. Today, shops and bars with colourful facades have recently established their neighbourhoods to make this now trendy place the iconic meeting place for food lovers.
Take advantage of the exotic flavours at Brixton Village; the covered market houses dozens of stalls inspired from around the globe. On the menu are giant crepes from Burnt Toast Café, generous burgers from Honest, Neapolitan pizzas from Franco Manca, Japanese fare from Kamone, chicken tikka masala from Hot Stuff and spicy meatballs from Mama Lan. To finish, wet your lips with a tea from Argentina or Ethiopia, and leave with some fruit from the West Indies.

Brixton Village
Coldharbour Lane
London SW9 8PS

brixtonmarket.net/brixton-village

content.title: Bar Termini, an address that brings together coffee and cocktails

introduction.small: Do you think that coffee and cocktails don't go together? Think again! The proof at Soho's Bar Termini.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Bar Termini, an address that brings together coffee and cocktails

paragraphs.text:
In the heart of vibrant Soho, Old Compton Street's number 7 hides a secret.
Bar Termini is a tiny place where only 25 people can find a seat, but it's well worth the trouble. Order a coffee or cocktail, depending on the hour and your preference. Marco Arrigo brilliantly manages the coffee side, transforming his beverages into works of art: the Affogato, an espresso with almond ice cream, is particularly delicious.
On the cocktail side, Tony Conigliaro takes over with equally exceptional creations. Give into the Death in Venice cocktail. Despite its frightening name, it will win you over with its delicate hints of Campari, grapefruit and Prosecco.
On the menu you will also find several different wines and small snacks: sliders, Italian cheese platters and beef carpaccio. How great!

Bar Termini
7 Old Compton Street
Soho
London W1D 5JE

+44 (0) 784 101 7138

www.bar-termini-soho.com

Coffee: from 2.50 GBP
Cocktails: 11 GBP

content.title: The Ned, the eighth wonder of the world

introduction.small: The Ned, an eight-storey tower of Babel in the vicinity of St. Paul's Cathedral. Relaxation and leisure in a five-star hotel.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Ned, the eighth wonder of the world

paragraphs.text:
Since its opening, The Ned has had a lot of buzz. Nick Jones, founder of Soho House, made the most of the beautiful Midland Bank building. Constructed in 1920, it was designed by famous English architect Edwin Landseer Lutyens, Ned to his friends. The entrepreneur embarked on a challenge: establishing a high-flying hotel conceived as a miniature city within the 30,000 sqm available to him. The success of this ambitious project has once again proved the undeniable qualities of the English hotel owner.

Ten restaurants welcome you, to eat to your heart's content: from stuffed armchairs at the Lutyens Grill, to the pale pink banquettes of Millie's Lounge, explore a dizzying culinary universe.

For hotel guests: manicures, hairdressing, steam rooms, and massages are all available. While the streets of London are bustling beyond the hotel walls, time stands still inside.

The Ned
27 Poultry
London EC2R 8AJ

+44 (0)20 3828 2000

www.thened.com

Rooms: from 300 GBP

content.title: Light up your nights at Isabel

introduction.small: In the heart of London, time for some good food at this new Albemarle Street spot. Welcome to Isabel.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Light up your nights at Isabel

paragraphs.text:
There is so much light in this new London address, signed Juan Santa Cruz! From the bar stools to the gilded ceiling, Isabel shines brightly. Bar, restaurant and club, it meets all the desires of visitors and Londoners alike, who come to taste the chef's dishes with an Argentine influence, and share a carefully mixed cocktail, or dance to furious rhythms.

From the mirrored, ebony bar to the hand-painted wallpaper of the restrooms, every detail of the establishment impresses. Sit comfortably on one of the black velvet banquettes, and get ready for a salad of sweet corn, spring onions, chilli, parsley and pomegranate, then a salmon fillet confit served with some dill dressing. Book a table as soon as you can!

Isabel

content.title: The Nobu Shoreditch, Japanese refinement

introduction.small: Elegance and contemporary design are the key words at Nobu's various addresses. Welcome to one of London's finest hotels.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Nobu Shoreditch, Japanese refinement

paragraphs.text:
With its geometric lines, dark colours, urban furniture, Japanese overtones, and subdued lighting, Nobu Shoreditch fascinates. The first establishment of the chain in Europe, its opening met all expectations. Mixing Japanese influences from his home country with London traditions, chef Nobu Matsuhisa was able to add a personal touch to the ambience of Shoreditch. The opening in this trendy area of ​​the capital is a boon for its founders, and the architects imagined several bars on different floors of the building to make the most of the space.

Take a stroll through the basement restaurant before relaxing on a delightfully shaded terrace or finishing your novel in the calm of the lobby. Later you can venture out to throbbing Shoreditch and its wild evenings.

Nobu Shoreditch
10-50 Willow Street

www.nobuhotelshoreditch.com

content.title: Dinings SW3: delicacies from elsewhere

introduction.small: The heritage of Japanese cuisine with added European touches, Dinings SW3 showcases Japanese gastronomy and offers a unique culinary experience.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Dinings SW3: delicacies from elsewhere

paragraphs.text:
Throughout the seasons, you will taste the subtle refinement of Japanese dishes served at Dinings SW3. The establishment aims to revisit traditional Japanese cuisine, drawing inspiration from European techniques and trends. A lovely fusion celebrated on Walton Street for a decade!

Light-coloured tiles, wooden tables, a bright counter… let the sophisticated and warm world of this izakaya (which is to Japan what a bistro or wine bar is to France, a pub to England or a tapas bar to Spain) transport you. Start with some appetizers: how about a vodka tonic infused with apple and cinnamon? Carry on your meal in good manners of mood and gastronomy: Scottish salmon with miso, braised cabbage with fresh truffle, open sushi rolls of foie gras and freshwater eel, Cornish crab meat with crispy onions and the like… Delights from everywhere in the heart of London.

Dinings SW3
Walton House

content.title: The Clarette, open to the world

introduction.small: Wine enthusiasts and connoisseurs take note! Head to La Clarette and discover an exceptional selection of wines.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Clarette, open to the world

paragraphs.text:
As the most beautiful vineyards of France are praised on the banks of the Thames, La Clarette is a unanimous success among Londoners. An urban and dynamic clientele rush to this Anglo-Norman farm building on a street corner. Inside, petrol blue banquettes run along antique pink coloured seats on either side of the bar.

Both a restaurant and wine bar, this friendly place run by Alexandra Petit-Mentzelopoulos offers wines from all over. They are accompanied by charming dishes to share, tapas-style, as well as creative and inspired meals such as duck confit served with marrow, figs and seeds granola.

You will be won over by the remarkable selection of excellent French and foreign wines. Wine by the glass or exceptional bottles await you for a personalised tasting moment.

Clarette Wine Bar

content.title: London History at the Four Seasons

introduction.small: The second London address of this Canadian group arrives near Trinity Square. Dive into the heart of a new hotel.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: London History at the Four Seasons

paragraphs.text:
On the banks of the Thames, this hotel elegantly crowns the Tower of London and overlooks the famous Tower bridge. Surrounded by the historic heart of the English capital, you will settle into a sleek bedroom, and appreciate its stunning marble bathroom. The neighbourhood of the City is all around you – experience its 2,000 years of exhilarating history.

With its impressive Corinthian columns, the former headquarters of the London Port Authority is also known for having housed the United Nations. Nowadays, you will find the most beautiful hotel rooms of the City there, as well as a large spa resembling Roman baths in Carrara marble, not mentioning the restaurant of French star chef Anne-Sophie Pic, also known as “La Dame de Pic”. Discover or rediscover London by reserving a room now!

Four Seasons

content.title: The charm of a private home at the Chiltern Firehouse

introduction.small: Live the hotel experience in a former London firehouse.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The charm of a private home at the Chiltern Firehouse

paragraphs.text:
Chiltern Firehouse, located in the heart of Marylebone district, is known for having been one of the first firehouses of London. The hotel, with 26 rooms and suites, was entirely restored by André Balazs, and joins the collection of luxury hotels of this famous hotelier who also has the Château Marmont in Los Angeles and the Mercer Hotel in New York. With its historical charm and very British decor, the Chiltern Firehouse will let you experience a unique stay, making you feel that you are stopping off in a private home. As for the restaurant, it offers many contemporary culinary specialties. Nuno Mendes, a Michelin-starred chef, gets his inspiration from time spent in the US and Europe to create a varied, savoury, inventive and audacious menu highlighting seasonal products.

Chiltern Firehouse
1 Chiltern Street
Marylebone
London W1U 7PA

+44 (0)20 7073 7676

www.chilternfirehouse.com

content.title: Grosvenor House, in the heart of London

introduction.small: Undeniably one of the most symbolic addresses in the London capital.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Grosvenor House, in the heart of London

paragraphs.text:
Ideally located in the heart of Mayfair, Grosvenor House-of the JW Marriott group-is one of the most popular places in London. A few steps from trendy bars and restaurants, the hotel is at the heart of luxury in a contemporary decor. You will make the most of a five-star stay in one of the recently updated suites, most of which have a view of Hyde Park. For your dining delight, you can have an excellent afternoon tea, winner of a “gastronomic Oscar” after a day of shopping on Oxford Street, then taste one of the best steaks in the city at the JW Steakhouse. Make sure you try the cheesecake, which is exceptional! For an even more British experience, try Corrigan's Mayfair, where you can choose from international dishes of all kinds, and end your evening at the Bourbon Bar for a taste of exceptional American whiskies or the Red Bar for a delicious cocktail.

JW Marriott - Grosvenor House

London W1K 7TN

+44 (0)20 7499 6363

www.marriott.fr

content.title: The Laslett, “Made in Notting Hill”

introduction.small: Proud of its roots, the Laslett has settled into Notting Hill and pays homage, in its way, to one of the symbolic personalities of the neighbourhood.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Laslett, “Made in Notting Hill”

paragraphs.text:
Located in the heart of Notting Hill, a stone's throw from Hyde Park, The Laslett hotel carries the name of the founder of the Notting Hill carnival (Rhaune Laslett), that occurs annually in the month of August.

The establishment's 51 rooms and suites are actually spread out through five Victorian landmark houses that Tracy Lowy, owner and art collector, has transformed into veritable cocoons that are both elegant and refined. For the decor, she has mixed design furniture, baubles and art objects of all kinds found in flea markets and antique shops on her travels or even on Portobello Road just a few steps away. For the restaurant, Tracy Lowy again turned to London heritage. Chef Sally Clarke, a major figure of gastronomy in London, creates typically British food at the Henderson. You will have understood that the Laslett is “so British”.

The Laslett
8 Pembridge Gardens
London W2 4DU

+44 (0)20 7792 6688

www.living-rooms.co.uk/hotel/the-laslett

Rooms: from 289 GBP

content.title: Core by Clare Smyth, the taste of success

introduction.small: Looking for an exceptional culinary experience in the English capital? Look no further, we have found an exquisite address for you in the heart of Notting Hill.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Core by Clare Smyth, the taste of success

paragraphs.text:
Core has access to the best products of British terroir, perfectly prepared and delicately assembled by an outstanding team with a shared passion for English gastronomy. They work in close collaboration with the farmers, producers and suppliers of the country to select ingredients of rare quality.

Clare Smyth, the first and only woman to run a 3-star Michelin restaurant in the UK, started cooking at the age of 16 and now runs this popular establishment of the capital. Focusing on the seasonality of products, she revisits the best of British cuisine with simplicity and creativity: langoustine and veal sweetbread served with fennel, carrot and vin jaune, oxtail stuffed with Roscoff onion, Morecambe bay shrimps with brown butter... There is something for everyone!

Core by Clare Smyth
92 Kensington Park Road
London W11 2PN

+44 (0)20 3937 5086

www.corebyclaresmyth.com

Menu: lunch from 65 GBP

content.title: Galvin HOP, chic bistro

introduction.small: After Galvin La Chapelle, starred chefs Chris and Jeff Galvin get on the bistronomy train with Galvin HOP.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Galvin HOP, chic bistro

paragraphs.text:
Taking up the spot of their former wine bar at Spitalfields, HOP is located right next to Galvin La Chapelle, their starred restaurant. This time, the kings of French brasserie in London are trying their hands at a chic London pub. Galvin HOP has all of the trimmings of a classical pub: an immense zinc bar, tiled walls, dark wood floors and bistro tables. The ambiance is casual, and you'll likely start a conversation with the folks at the next table over. In short, Galvin HOP has all the attractions of a local pub.
However, the revolution is in the kitchen! The traditional brasserie cooking has been notched up with a bistronomic accent. The chefs even make suggestions for beer and food pairings, like great restaurants do with wines. Definitely go for the Galvin Dog Deluxe, a hot dog with truffle mustard that you can even order to takeaway.

Galvin HOP
35 Spital Square
London E1 6DY
+44 (0)20 7299 0404

www.galvinrestaurants.com/galvinhop

Menu: around 15 GBP

content.title: Z Shoreditch, a room and that's it

introduction.small: In the vibrant area of ​​East London, the Z Hotel is a good alternative to local hotels.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Z Shoreditch, a room and that's it

paragraphs.text:
Ideal for a short stay and very well located in Shoreditch, the Z Hotel offers compact and comfortable accommodation. As the British would say: "You're not going to hold a conference in your room!" In London, the chain's sixth hotel has a successful formula. With a bed-loft, the room is great for families, and has “no curtain to pull” (i.e. no windows). Suitcases fit under the bed and there is even a little desk. As for the bathroom, it is functional without loss of space. Trendy Shoreditch has much to offer. The hotel is located next to Ceviche Old Street, one of the best Peruvian restaurants in the city, with very affordable prices (meals costs around 11 GBP). And, at the hotel, do not miss the cheese and wine aperitif from 5 to 8 p.m.

The Z Hotel Shoreditch
136-144 City Road
London EC1V 2RL

+44 (0)20 3551 3700

www.thezhotels.com/hotels/shoreditch

content.title: Dishoom King's Cross, a journey in itself

introduction.small: Indian flavours from breakfast to dinner... This place is a must.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Dishoom King's Cross, a journey in itself

paragraphs.text:
Behind St Pancras station, the journey continues to Bombay in a capsule that takes you back in time to the 20s, 30s and 40s. This former brick warehouse houses Dishoom, inspired by the old Irani cafes in Mumbai opened by Iranian Zoroastrians in the last century. There, students, lawyers, drivers and families share tables. Dishoom has transported this welcoming ambience to London amid vintage furniture and antique objects that include a second-class train banquette seat, an old clock from the Mumbai Central Railway Station, and a newsstand turned into juice bar... Everything is an invitation to ‘elsewhere', starting with dishes like chicken tikka, black daal and naan cheese, among others. Londoners, who are connoisseurs of Indian cuisine, love it here. If you like spicy food, Dishoom also has restaurants in Shoreditch, Soho and Covent Garden.

Dishoom Covent Garden

content.title: Sexy Fish: a fish named desire

introduction.small: The new restaurant that all London is talking about, a place to see and to be seen.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Sexy Fish: a fish named desire

paragraphs.text:
The latest from the Caprice group (The Ivy, Daphne's, Scott's) just opened its doors in Mayfair. With a name like Sexy Fish, you draw attention! The concept has been carefully studied: elaborate food inspired by the seas of Asia and prepared by chef Ben Orpwood and his team, irresistible cocktails, impeccable service, and a cheerful atmosphere, all in a designer setting.

Three sculptures by Damien Hirst and a four-meter crocodile in silicone mosaic signed by Frank Gehry provide some of the finishing touches to the decor created by Martin Brudnizki Design Studio.

And for an even more exclusive meal, the Sexy Fish has The Coral Reef Room downstairs, which you can reserve for up to 48 people, with two of the largest reef aquariums in the world. Notice to Japanese whiskey lovers: the Sexy Fish bar has the most impressive European collection of this irresistible drink. Book well in advance.

Sexy Fish
Berkeley Square House

Greater London W1J 6BR

+44 (0)207 3764 2000

www.sexyfish.com

content.title: Ace Hotel: a breath of fresh air

introduction.small: An atypical ambiance and decor for a super-trendy hotel.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Ace Hotel: a breath of fresh air

paragraphs.text:
This new Ace Hotel opened in 2013 in Shoreditch, the first address of Ace Group hotel chain outside the US. In keeping with the area of East London, this five-star hotel is extremely trendy, but also relaxed, and attracts a young, creative, and connected clientele.

A breath of fresh air for hotels in London, the 265 rooms and suites offer modern decor with a minimalist style. The staff may appear relaxed, but they provide excellent service. Loud music is played in the lobby, and parties take place on weekends with DJs, but don't worry about the soundproofing: everything has been studied in detail. As an amusing touch, you can listen to a story before you go to sleep through a system of bedtime stories available in each room; you may also find vinyl records and turntables next to your bed.

A 24-hour sauna is a bonus, and bicycles are also available to residents.

Ace Hotel
100 Shoreditch High Street
London E1 6JQ
+44 (0)20 7613 9800

www.acehotel.com/london

content.title: SUSHISAMBA : cuisine to make you dizzy

introduction.small: A rare treat it is, in London, to go up to the 38th floor for dinner. Having towers of bamboo above and outstanding views beyond only adds to the unique experience.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: SUSHISAMBA : cuisine to make you dizzy

paragraphs.text:
The SushiSamba group opened its first restaurant in New York in 1999, offering customers exceptional cuisine with Japanese, Brazilian, and Peruvian influences. After this first success, they added locations in Miami Beach, Las Vegas, and London.

Offering a stunning 360° view atop the Salesforce Tower (including a perfect angle on the magnificent building affectionately nicknamed the “Gherkin” by Londoners), the chef Claudio Cardoso and his team promise you some startling cuisine to match the unusual space. Enjoy the Samba brunch, an absolutely delicious breakfast, or the sea bass tempura served with tomato and beetroot ceviche, green garlic and lime. Try the mochis, small and round Japanese rice cakes, very soft and stuffed with ice cream, usually covered with a white chocolate sauce. An explosion of colours and flavours!

Reservations strongly recommended and dress code to be respected.

SushiSamba
110 Bishopsgate
London EC2N 4AY

+44 (0)20 3640 7330

www.sushisamba.com/location/london

Menu: around 32 GBP

content.title: Natural History Museum: for natural history buffs of all ages

introduction.small: An afternoon won't be enough to take in all the museum has to offer.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Natural History Museum: for natural history buffs of all ages

paragraphs.text:
In South Kensington, near the Science Museum and the Victoria and Albert Museum, the world-famous Natural History Museum has a breath-taking collection of over 80 million specimens covering billions of years.

Upon your arrival, the building's Romanesque architecture will first captivate you, after which you'll move on to see the treasures of the museum, ranging from Darwin's samples to gigantic dinosaur bones and the collections gathered from the travels of explorer James Cook. You simply cannot miss the 25-metre-long blue whale skeleton, now replacing Dippy, the diplodocus that stood for decades in the lobby.

The museum is divided into four zones to facilitate the visit. Each year, the Natural History Museum welcomes more than 5 million visitors. Admission is free and there is often a queue, but don't worry, it moves rather quickly.

Natural History Museum
Cromwell Road
SW7 5BD

+44 (0)20 7942 5000

www.nhm.ac.uk

content.title: Dishoom: Indian cuisine from breakfast until late

introduction.small: A bacon naan roll to start your day or an East Indian Gimlet to finish your evening, the Dishoom restaurants have delicious dishes on offer all day long.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Dishoom: Indian cuisine from breakfast until late

paragraphs.text:
Fashioned after the ‘Irani Cafés', mythical 19th-century eateries in India run by Persian immigrants, the Dishoom addresses maintain some of the exotic ambiance of yesteryear in their unique dishes and drinks.

The teams at these street-food inspired eateries will be happy to explain the menu and direct you to the dishes that will suit your cravings. Depending on your preferences and your tolerance for spicy food, you can enjoy delicious Indo-British-Iranian cuisine throughout the day. Perhaps a bun maska, a buttery bun, to dip in your chai? Or maybe lamb samosas with Gujarati filo and okra fries, or an Iranian inspired Biryani, a slow-cooked dish to be shared; all are tasty and affordable options, whatever the hour. The Dishoom restaurants are in Covent Garden, Shoreditch, Carnaby, and King's Cross.

They are open almost every day of the year from 8:00 a.m. to 11:00 p.m., Friday and Saturday until midnight.

Dishoom Covent Garden
12 Upper St. Martin's Lane
London
WC2H 9FB

Dishoom King's Cross
5 Stable Street
London N1C 4AB

Dishroom Shoreditch
7 Boundary Street
London E2 7JE

Dishoom Carnaby
22 Kingly Street
London W1B 5QP

+44 (0) 20 7420 9320

www.dishoom.com

Menu: around 16 GBP

content.title: Sofitel London St James: the heart of London

introduction.small: From this perfect location in the centre of London, you'll be able to organize your outings with ease.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Sofitel London St James: the heart of London

paragraphs.text:
Sofitel St James, a five-star hotel, combines traditional British design with contemporary French style. Pale green, brown and grey tones decorate the 183 rooms and suites, which have furniture with clean lines and fabulous Sofitel bedding. Le Balcon, a refined brasserie, serves French-British cuisine prepared by chef Vincent Menager, who learned the trade with Alain Ducasse and Frédéric Anton. To enjoy afternoon tea to the sounds of a harp, settle into the intimate Rose Lounge. With decor inspired by the Parisian apartment of Coco Chanel, the St. James Bar offers a wide selection of vintage Champagnes and original cocktails. Finally, SoSpa offers exceptional treatments with Carita and Cinq Mondes products, as well as those of the sublime and iconic actress Marisa Berenson. The Sofitel St James has everything you need, and in a great location, too.

Sofitel London St James
6 Waterloo Place
London SW1Y 4AN

+44 (0)20 7747 2200

www.sofitel.com/fr/hotel-3144-sofitel-londres-st-james/index.shtml

Rooms: from 280 GBP

content.title: Covent Garden: a lively and warm “village”

introduction.small: Formerly one of the most visited food markets in London, Covent Garden now attracts the crowds for shopping and eating in a more modern setting.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Covent Garden: a lively and warm “village”

paragraphs.text:
Covent Garden is a timeless place with very few cars, many people, and a lot of shops. The smallest stand sells badges bearing the image of the Beatles right next to the flagship store of the largest luxury brand. With its columns, covered market, street performers, and classical singers who perform while you enjoy an irresistible Shake Shack burger.

Covent Garden is a West End district, a monument, and a small village all to its own. The Royal Opera House is right next to the market, as is the Transport Museum, and the London Film Museum. The superb Apple Store is here as well, as are an abundance of little streets, St. Paul's Church, 13 theatres, the Balthazar brasserie, and pubs every two metres.

Don't be caught off guard by the Covent Garden Underground station, which has a spiral staircase of more than 200 steps.

Covent Garden
London WC2E

https://www.coventgarden.london/

content.title: Saatchi Gallery: more than a gallery, a museum

introduction.small: For an artist, having an exhibit at the Saatchi Gallery is one of the world's most beautiful launch pads.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Saatchi Gallery: more than a gallery, a museum

paragraphs.text:
Founded in 1985 in North London by Charles Saatchi to present his own art collection, this superb contemporary art gallery relocated twice before moving to Chelsea in October 2008. The current building of 5,000 square metres is better known as the Duke of York's Headquarters (or HQ).

The Saatchi Gallery highlights the work of young British and foreign artists who have rarely or never been exhibited. After a Saatchi show, they often see their popularity rating climb considerably. At times, the gallery has masterful exhibitions, as was the case with “Mademoiselle Privé” orchestrated by Karl Lagerfeld to retrace the life of Coco Chanel.

In the past five years, the Saatchi Gallery has hosted 15 of the 20 most-visited exhibitions in London. This is a unique place that we visit for fun, because we know that amazing works are always presented, and also because the gallery shop is outstanding!

Saatchi Gallery
Duke of York's HQ
King's Road
London SW3 4RY

+44 (0)20 7811 3070

www.saatchigallery.com

content.title: Aman Spa: a paradise in the city

introduction.small: In the midst of Mayfair, a trip to the East.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Aman Spa: a paradise in the city

paragraphs.text:
Temple of wellness and relaxation, the Aman Spa at the Hotel Connaught is the perfect oasis in which to relax after a long day of sightseeing or shopping. Leave the Edwardian decor of the 5-star hotel behind, as well as the sometimes exhausting energy of London to escape eastward.

Opt for one of the “signature” care packages from around the world: China, Thailand, India, or North America, where the sublime Aman institutions have taken up residence. Count on spending two-and-a-half hours for this moment of absolute happiness.

Special treatments have been developed for travellers, mothers-to-be, and new mothers, as well as others in search of alternative medicines. You can ask for traditional beauty treatments too. In addition to five treatment rooms, there is an up-to-the-minute gym, a steam room, and a sublime ionized pool of 60 square metres.

Aman Spa
Hotel Connaught
Carlos Place
London W1K 2AL

+44 (0)20 3147 7305

www.the-connaught.co.uk/aman-spa/

content.title: Borough Market: pause for a bite

introduction.small: A thousand and one colours, savours, and smells… out of the rain.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Borough Market: pause for a bite

paragraphs.text:
Described as one of the largest, best, and most beautiful of food markets, Borough Market is located just steps from the River Thames in southeast London, where it serves tourists and Londoners alike.

This covered market is reserved for professionals from 2:00 a.m. to 8:00 a.m., but later opens to the public from 10:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. (6:00 p.m. on Fridays; closed Sundays). A gourmet paradise, you will be tempted at each of the more than 100 stands. Products from England and around the world, are of exceptional quality; exotic fruits, meats, fish, spices, breads, and cheeses are just some of the delicious things you'll find.

To go shopping, have lunch, walk around, or enjoy some of the tastings, the Borough Market will not disappoint. You will also be able to call up memories of your visit by looking up recipes on their website when you get home.

Borough Market
8 Southwark Street
London SE1 1TL

+44 (0) 20 7407 1002

www.boroughmarket.org.uk

content.title: National Portrait Gallery: for ‘face-to-face' encounters

introduction.small: You will be able to look straight into the eyes of thousands of famous people.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: National Portrait Gallery: for ‘face-to-face' encounters

paragraphs.text:
First opened in 1856, the National Portrait Gallery has been located close to Trafalgar Square since 1896. This top portrait gallery in the world showcases all forms of representations, from drawings, paintings, cartoons, and photographs to sculptures.

The institution presents an impressive collection of 200,000 historical and contemporary portraits, with representations of living persons being authorized as of 1969. Each portrait was chosen not for the merits of the artist, but for the quality of its subject. Expect to see the faces of the most iconic British personalities: William Shakespeare, Oscar Wilde, and Queen Victoria, as well as rocker Sir Mick Jagger. Catherine Middleton, Duchess of Cambridge, was inducted in 2013.

In addition, the National Portrait Gallery hosts exhibitions like the one dedicated to Audrey Hepburn, a huge success. Soon, Vogue magazine will have a retrospective to mark the 100th anniversary of its British edition.

National Portrait Gallery
St Martin's Place
London WC2H 0HE

+44 (0)20 7306 0055

www.npg.org.uk

content.title: Original Tours: Visit London on the double-decker bus

introduction.small: To explore the city, don't be afraid to be a tourist!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Original Tours: Visit London on the double-decker bus

paragraphs.text:
Starting off your stay in London with a double-decker bus tour will help you better find your way around on your own. London is immense, covering more than 1,500 square kilometres, so it is worth taking a tour or two to see the highlights without the headache of understanding the regular city buses. You can choose between three different tour-bus routes with a total of 80 possible stops. Your ticket is good for 24 hours and lets you get on or off at will on any given route.

The “Original Tour”, indicated in yellow, and the “City Sightseeing Tour”, in red, both cover the most iconic London landmarks such as Buckingham Palace, Big Ben, and the Houses of Parliament, Downing Street, The London Dungeon, Tower Bridge, and the Tower of London. A third option, “The Museum Tour”, indicated in blue, serves most of London's museums including the British Museum and the Natural History Museum.

All three tours are accompanied by audio commentary describing the points of interest along the route. Enjoy!

The Original London Visitor Centre
17-19 Cockspur Street
Trafalgar Square
London
SW1Y 5BL

+44 (0)20 8877 1722

www.theoriginaltour.com

content.title: Sofitel London St James: the heart of London

introduction.small: From this perfect location in the centre of London, you'll be able to organize your outings with ease.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Sofitel London St James: the heart of London

paragraphs.text:
The Sofitel London  St James, a five-star hotel, combines traditional British design with contemporary French style. Pale green, brown and grey tones decorate the 183 rooms, including 18 suites, which have furniture with clean lines and fabulous Sofitel bedding.

Le Balcon, a refined brasserie, serves French-British cuisine prepared by chef Matt Greenwood. To enjoy afternoon tea to the sounds of a harp, settle into the intimate Rose Lounge. With decor inspired by the Parisian apartment of Coco Chanel, the St. James Bar offers a wide selection of vintage Champagnes and original cocktails.

Finally, SoSpa offers exceptional treatments with Carita and Cinq Mondes products, as well as those of the sublime and iconic actress Marisa Berenson. The Sofitel St James has everything you need, and in a great location, too.

+44 (0)20 7747 2200

content.title: Les Petits Gourmets: they grow quickly!

introduction.small: This “little brother” in the Maida Vale neighbourhood, follows in the footsteps of Les Gourmets des Ternes in Knightsbridge, which is, in turn, named after the original address in Paris.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Les Petits Gourmets: they grow quickly!

paragraphs.text:
The grandson of the founder of the Parisian bistro, Gourmets des Ternes, wanted to replicate the authentic cuisine that has made the reputation of his grandfather's restaurant in Paris since 1962. After opening a branch in Knightsbridge, the family business has expanded here to Formosa Street.

If the menu is not exactly the same, the quality and style are. A red and grey awning and a French team welcome you in a pretty alley near Little Venice. Here, there is no culinary revolution but rather a successful traditional cuisine: depending on the season, you'll find white asparagus, snails in garlic, chicken supreme in creamy mushrooms and truffle oil... Of course, a cheese platter is available, as well as a selection of macaroons or a perfectly executed tarte tatin. The atmosphere is as convivial as in Paris, and is especially charming when professionals or amateurs sit at the 1896 piano to entertain the other guests.

Les Petits Gourmets
18 Formosa Street
London W9 1EE

+44 (0) 207 286 3742

www.lespetitsgourmetslondon.co.uk

Menu: around 26 GBP

content.title: The Blues Kitchen: the pub!

introduction.small: A London institution with three addresses in Camden, Brixton and Shoreditch.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Blues Kitchen: the pub!

paragraphs.text:
As soon as you walk through the door of the Blues Kitchen, you will not be able to say whether you are in London or somewhere in the south of the United States. What is great about this restaurant, besides the live music, is that you can pop in at any time; hearty breakfasts and good food are served throughout the day.

You can also come for dinner or just for a drink: a fabulous bar with an impressive choice of cocktails, beers, and whiskeys awaits you, just like the musicians who perform live every night.

Pete Doherty even stops by to strum his guitar from time to time. The service is friendly and efficient, the clientele eclectic. Whatever the day and whoever the artist, a night at the Blues Kitchen promises a lively and fun atmosphere. Note that if you're intolerant or allergic, the burger buns can be ordered gluten-free!

The Blues Kitchen
111-113 Camden High Street
Camden
London NW1 7JN

+44 (0)20 7387 5277

www.theblueskitchen.com/camden

Menu: around 24 GBP

content.title: Charlotte Street Hotel: in the footsteps of Virginia Woolf

introduction.small: Located in the famous Bloomsbury area, a few metres from the British Museum, this hotel is part of the Firmdale Hotel Group, which also owns the Haymarket.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Charlotte Street Hotel: in the footsteps of Virginia Woolf

paragraphs.text:
The 52 rooms and suites at Charlotte Street Hotel are spacious, colourful and bright, and bear the touch of the designer and owner, Kit Kemp.

A mixture of contemporary style and antiques, with walls in solid colours that contrast with the printed fabrics of various patterns, particularly on oversized headboards and sofas, give the place the feeling of a family estate. The artworks are signed by the Bloomsbury Group, that club of artists and British intellectuals that included Duncan Grant, Roger Fry, and Vanessa Bell, the sister of Virginia Woolf, the central member of the group. The staff is discreet, attentive, and highly effective.

While there is not a separate spa in the hotel, you can have spa treatments provided in the comfort of your room. The Oscar bar and restaurant provides a warm setting for breakfast, and then continues service throughout the day for lunch, tea, or a cocktail.

Charlotte Street Hotel
15-17 Charlotte Street
London W1T 1RJ

+44 (0)20 7806 2000

www.firmdalehotels.com

Rooms: from 312 GBP

content.title: Hotpod Yoga: an adventure that is, well, hot!

introduction.small: A permanent address on Helmsley Place with continued ‘ephemeral' sessions in Brixton and Notting Hill.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hotpod Yoga: an adventure that is, well, hot!

paragraphs.text:
Yoga has new followers every day worldwide, many need to disconnect from an overly stressful and fast-paced urban life. Londoners are no exception. Nick Higgins and Max Henderson had the idea of offering high-temperature yoga in a “Hotpod”, a mobile yoga studio.

Indeed, they have developed inflatable cocoons that are heated to 37°C in which up to 25 people can gather to do their Vinyasa sessions, a sort of cousin to Bikram yoga with shorter, 45-minute classes and a slightly lower temperature.

After ephemeral sessions in Brixton and Notting Hill, which will continue, the two young men now have a permanent location on Helmsley Place in a permanent studio that offers its customers a shower, juice bar, and changing room.

Hotpod Yoga
9-15 Helmsley Place
London Fields
E8 3SB

+44 (0)20 3771 2285

www.hotpodyoga.com

content.title: Primrose Hill: on the heels of the Rolling Stones

introduction.small: Londoners love to walk, run, and picnic in their many green spaces. There is more than just Hyde Park to explore!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Primrose Hill: on the heels of the Rolling Stones

paragraphs.text:
Put on some comfortable shoes, essential for any trip to London, and climb up Primrose Hill, formerly part of the hunting grounds of King Henry VIII. A delightful place with stunning views over London. The Rolling Stones put the park on the album cover of “Between the Buttons”.

For Paul McCartney, a strange meeting on Primrose Hill inspired “The Fool On The Hill”, recorded in September 1967, at the Abbey Road studios nearby. A walk on Primrose Hill is highly recommended as a way of finding peace after a trip to Camden Market. If you haven't already had a meal on your way here, you can lunch at The Engineer pub, or brunch on a weekend at Greenberry Café, a neighbourhood institution.

Then gear up for a shopping spree on Regent's Park Road, at Elias & Grace (for children) and at Anna (for their moms), the latter offering a beautiful selection of designer clothing and accessories.

Primrose Hill
Primrose Hill Road
London NW3

content.title: Fortnum & Mason: temple of tea and quality groceries

introduction.small: This teashop in Piccadilly, with a 300-year history, offers ‘hampers' full of delicious foods, marmalades, wines, teas, and biscuits to give a taste of England to friends at home.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Fortnum & Mason: temple of tea and quality groceries

paragraphs.text:
This brand, created in 1707 by William Fortnum and Hugh Mason, is the uncontested reference for fine teas and luxury products, and has been an official supplier of the royal family for 150 years.

Queen Elisabeth surely has her favourites among the delicacies purchased here and Prince Charles swears by their brand of tea. Enter into this very British universe with all the finest ingredients: a diverse selection of teas and coffees, tasty biscuits in music boxes, mustards and chutneys, marmalades and other confections that will be quickly devoured, but only after appreciating the fine wrappers and boxes.

Or go for one of the iconic gift baskets or ‘hampers' marked with ‘F&M' that have made its worldwide success. Walk the fresh-market aisles, then explore the different floors, for this palace of wonders contains many tasty surprises.

Fortnum & Mason
181 Piccadilly
London W1A 1ER

+44 (0)20 7734 8040

www.fortnumandmason.com

content.title: Buckingham Palace: strut your way to the royal family

introduction.small: The residence of Queen Elizabeth II and her famous guards will provide you with a royal show.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Buckingham Palace: strut your way to the royal family

paragraphs.text:
Built in 1702 by the Duke who gave it its name, Buckingham Palace has been the official residence of the British monarch since Queen Victoria's accession to the throne in 1837; the Palace is also the administrative headquarters of the monarchy.

The 77,000 square meters of the Palace contain an impressive 775 rooms and serves as the official place of reception by Queen Elizabeth and the Duke of Edinburgh for state visits, royal ceremonies, investitures, and ennoblements.

The State Rooms are open to the public daily in the summer and at more limited times at other periods of the year, when not in official use. The Queen's Gallery, opened in 2002, showcasing artwork of the Royal Collection can be visited all year. Do not miss the inevitable changing of the guard every day at 11:30 a.m. from early April to late July, and every other day the rest of the year.

Buckingham Palace
London SW1A 1AA

www.royalcollection.org.uk
www.householddivision.org.uk

content.title: NOPI Restaurant: Mediterranean-inspired cooking north of the Channel

introduction.small: Sumptuous cuisine at one of the most in-vogue restaurants of London, Yotam Ottolenghi and his team are ‘serious about making people happy through our food'.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: NOPI Restaurant: Mediterranean-inspired cooking north of the Channel

paragraphs.text:
After developing a loyal customer base at his four Ottolenghi restaurants, as well as racking up additional fans with his many cookbooks, the talented Israeli chef Yotam Ottolenghi has elevated his bold Middle Eastern recipes to a more sophisticated level with NOPI, (short for North of Piccadilly). Since opening in 2011, this restaurant, located a five-minute walk from Piccadilly Circus station, has offered a delicious Mediterranean-inspired menu that evolves with the seasons.

Two atmospheres exist within the same institution: the upstairs is more formal than the downstairs dining room, which is composed of two large common tables that look onto the kitchens run by chef Ramael Scully.

Get ready to be surprised by a true festival of flavours and some sincere smiles from the staff. Open from breakfast onwards, NOPI also proposes pre-theatre dinners. Don't forget to specify when booking if you prefer to be upstairs or downstairs.

NOPI Restaurant
21-22 Warwick Street
London W1B 5NE

+44 (0)207 7494 9584

www.ottolenghi.co.uk/nopi

Menu: around 34 GBP

content.title: Hotel 41: haute couture of hotels

introduction.small: A few metres from Buckingham Palace, English-style luxury.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hotel 41: haute couture of hotels

paragraphs.text:
The Hotel 41 is a five-star refuge, located opposite the residence of Queen Elizabeth and formerly a part of the royal park.

This hotel is a gem of intimacy and excellence, having won many awards from tourism professionals. Wood panelling in the hallways and black-and-white design in most of the 30 luxurious and unique rooms and suites remind one of the clubs of the gentry. As for the staff, they are twice as numerous as customers, which allows them to provide exceptional service 24 hours a day.

A butler will be at your disposal for the duration of your stay and will meet all your demands. “Customer is king” has never felt truer".

Hotel 41
41 Buckingham Palace Road
London SW1W 0PS

+44 (0)20 7300 0041

www.41hotel.com

Rooms: from 388 GBP

content.title: Artist Residence: welcome home

introduction.small: The ideal hotel for those who love authenticity and beauty.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Artist Residence: welcome home

paragraphs.text:
At first glance, this could be a beautiful private home into which you may like to be invited. Once the threshold is crossed, you understand that you will love staying here. Selected for the popular “Hot List 2015” by Condé Nast Traveler magazine, Artist Residence is situated in Pimlico, about five minutes from Victoria Station.

You will feel at home in one of the ten unique rooms. Charlie and Justin, the young owners, wanted their hotel to be charming without being pretentious, comfortable and refined without being outrageously expensive. They used wood, brick, and antique furniture with a bit of pop art mixed in to satisfy this aim.

The service is discreet and very effective. You can visit the hotel's restaurant, The Cambridge Street, to take a good breakfast, nibble something for lunch or to discover more elaborate dishes in the evening, always in a friendly atmosphere.

Artist Residence
52 Cambridge Street
London SW1V 4QQ

+44 (0)20 7828 6684

www.artistresidencelondon.co.uk/

Rooms: from 240 GBP

content.title: Kew Gardens: flowers for the Queen

introduction.small: 15 kilometres from the centre of London, near the Thames, discover the majesty of the Kew Royal Botanic Gardens, a beauty to behold in all four seasons.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Kew Gardens: flowers for the Queen

paragraphs.text:
Declared a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 2003, Kew Gardens contains not only collections of rare plants and iconic gardens and greenhouses, but also a royal palace and three art galleries on its 121 hectares.

Everything has been designed for visitors to spend a pleasant day on site with cafés, restaurants, and even playgrounds for children. Check out the Japanese garden of 5,000 square meters with a Magnolia kobus tree, native of Japan, planted by Her Imperial Highness Princess Sayako in 1996. So many delights are here to be discovered that it is difficult to see everything on just one trip.

To make the most of your day, think of booking your entry tickets online in advance and consider the option of taking the small train that will help you discover the beauty of the gardens and provide you with explanations of the different areas.

Kew Gardens
Kew
Richmond
Surrey TW9 3AB

+44 (0)20 8332 5655

www.kew.org

content.title: The London Eye: if for nothing but the view

introduction.small: An essential stop to rise above London's crowds if only for a moment. Located on the Thames, you can see most of the city's landmarks on your ride in the sky.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The London Eye: if for nothing but the view

paragraphs.text:
Located on the right bank of the River Thames to mark the millennial transition to the year 2000, the London Eye is one of the most impressive Ferris wheels in the world.

It took seven years to construct, from conception to completion, a project inspired by David Marks and Julia Barfield, two architects who wanted to give London its 21st century Eiffel Tower. At a weight of 2,100 tonnes, the London Eye has 32 futuristic glass gondolas capable of carrying 25 people each. Over 3.5 million visitors come each year, and you too can enjoy your rise to 135 metres to contemplate the spectacular panoramic views that spread over 40 kilometres.

Dusk is the perfect time to admire St. Paul's Cathedral, Westminster Abbey, and Buckingham Palace during the 30 minutes that the wheel turns. Do not forget to book your tickets online to avoid having to wait before going up to touch the stars!

The London Eye
London SE1 7PB

+44 (0)87 0990 8881

www.londoneye.com

content.title: Camden Market: from underground to picturesque

introduction.small: A worthy outing to a colourful London neighbourhood, with shops, cafés, and pubs, on weekdays or weekends.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Camden Market: from underground to picturesque

paragraphs.text:
Originally an underground scene, the Camden Market is now one of the major tourist attractions in London. You can buy the latest fashions, have a bite to eat, or check out the books, art, and collectibles here. The most famous area is Camden Lock, whose eponymous locks are on the Regent's Canal, north of Regent's Park.

If you are in the mood for a crowd, come on a weekend for a boisterous atmosphere, or opt for a weekday if you prefer a more leisurely stroll. In either case, enjoy the storefronts decorated with whimsical sculptures or the stalls selling vintage clothes, original crafts, or international cuisine.

Finish off your walk with a beer in memory of Amy Winehouse at her favourite pub, The Hawley Arms.

Camden Market
56 Camden Lock Place
London NW1 8AF

+44 (0)20 3763 9900

www.camdenmarket.com

content.title: Saint Paul's Cathedral: a monumental work of art

introduction.small: It is impossible not to succumb to the majesty of this building that has survived bombs and hosted the 'wedding of the century'.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Saint Paul's Cathedral: a monumental work of art

paragraphs.text:
Masterpiece of the British architect, Christopher Wren, St Paul's Cathedral is at the top of Ludgate Hill, in the heart of The City, the financial district of London and its historic centre. Icon of the capital since its construction was completed in 1710, the classical and baroque cathedral became a symbol of resistance when it escaped the Blitz during the Second World War, when 16 of Wren's other churches were destroyed.

The crypt of St. Paul's Cathedral contains the tombs of many important English personalities such as Admiral Nelson and the Duke of Wellington. The cathedral has been the scene of major events such as the funeral of Winston Churchill in 1965 and the wedding of Lady Diana to Prince Charles in 1981.

St. Paul's is often used in major films to show that the action is happening in London, as in Harry Potter or Mary Poppins. Explore the 150 metres of its nave, climb the 259 steps for a tour of the whispering gallery or, if you are feeling athletic, walk up the 528 steps to the top of its dome to discover a breath-taking panorama.

St Paul's Churchyard
London EC4M 8AD

+44 (0)20 7236 4128

www.stpauls.co.uk

content.title: Westminster Abbey: a rendezvous with history

introduction.small: Built in the 11th century and rebuilt in 1245, Westminster Abbey marks the important moments of the British royalty, from coronations to weddings and funerals.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Westminster Abbey: a rendezvous with history

paragraphs.text:
In this majestic Gothic church, Prince William, Duke of Cambridge, married Catherine Middleton in 2011; 14 years previously, he had come here with other family and friends to say goodbye to his mother, Lady Diana. So goes the life and times of Westminster Abbey, a fixture on momentous occasions in the lives of the royal family. A UNESCO World Heritage Site since 1985, Westminster Abbey, whose formal name is the Collegiate Church of St. Peter at Westminster, also houses the tombs of many prominent British figures from Isaac Newton to Charles Darwin.

Do not miss the “Poets' Corner” where monuments are erected to the glory of writers such as William Shakespeare, Charles Dickens, and Rudyard Kipling, and the abbey museum, housed in the vaulted crypt of Saint Peter, one of the oldest parts of the church.

A visit here is still a must during a stay in the British capital, as Westminster Abbey is steeped in history. Photographs are prohibited inside this sacred place.

Westminster Abbey
20 Deans Yard
London SW1P 3PA

+44 (0)20 7222 5152

www.westminster-abbey.org

content.title: The Beaumont: return to interwar London

introduction.small: When two restaurateurs try their hand at hotel management, the result is a real gem.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Beaumont: return to interwar London

paragraphs.text:
Chris Corbin and Jeremy King earned their stripes with their restaurants the Wolseley, the Delauney, and the Colbert. Their first hotel has also met with resounding success. Located in Mayfair, between Selfridges and Grosvenor Square, The Beaumont is away from the noise and bustle of Oxford Street.

In a historic building from 1926, it offers 73 rooms and suites, including a presidential suite that can measure more than 600 square metres, depending on the customer's preferred layout. The Art Deco style of the hotel's facade is faithfully reflected throughout the rooms with marble, mahogany, large black-and-white portraits. The bathrooms have their floors covered with the same beautiful mosaic tiles that are found in the spa.

The comfort and service are the height of luxury and in keeping with the quality of the decor. Dive into the London of yesteryear when you're here, with a drink in the (residents only) Cub Room.

The Beaumont
8 Balderton St
Brown Hart Gardens
London W1K 6TF

+44 (0)207 7499 1001

www.thebeaumont.com

Rooms: from 392 GBP

content.title: Experimental Cocktail Club (ECC) Chinatown: a unique experience

introduction.small: A totally unexpected bar in London's Chinatown. Come for a drink, stay for a while.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Experimental Cocktail Club (ECC) Chinatown: a unique experience

paragraphs.text:
After initiating Paris in the art of cocktail bars with the award-winning Curio Parlour, the Prescription and the Beef Club Ballroom, the Experimental Cocktail Club trio of Romée de Goriainoff, Olivier Bon and Pierre-Charles Cros have exported to London their latest European incarnation of New York's secret bars, such as Death & Company, Milk & Honey, and PDT.

In elegant surroundings created by rising designer Dorothée Meilichzon, and a location on three floors in the heart of London's Chinatown, ECC Chinatown offers a cocktail menu limited to nine unique creations and five other specialties created by the best bartenders in the world.

Bookings are highly recommended but not mandatory the club reserves half of their spots for walk-ins. You can also try Compagnie des Vins Supernatural Seven Dials or Joyeux Bordel, two other ECC establishments with names that make you wonder. Open until 3:00 a.m. most nights, and now on Sunday until midnight.

Experimental Cocktail Club Chinatown
13 A Gerrard Street
London W1D 5PS

www.chinatownecc.com

Menu: around 11.50 GBP

content.title: Mazi: “together” and that's all you need to know

introduction.small: Visiting London is the occasion to discover cuisines of all kinds. Take a side trip to Greece at Mazi!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Mazi: “together” and that's all you need to know

paragraphs.text:
Notting Hill has always had a lot of excellent, unexpected spots, and what a nice surprise Mazi is! The name of the restaurant means 'together' in Greek and, indeed, this is a sunny interlude that you'll be happy to share with a friend or loved one in a city with weather that is sometimes in need of cheering up. A French-Greek couple, Christina and Adrian, let you feast on Greek flavours here.

As a starter, taramasalata, tzatziki and grilled eggplant with soy and thyme honey are served in verrines. For the next course, it's difficult to choose between the grilled octopus, Beluga lentils and lemon-yuzu oil, or the braised osso buco with Mizithra flakes (cheese from the Attica region). For dessert, give in to the loukoumades, deep-fried dough with lavender honey accompanied by a chocolate sorbet. This is an ideal place for fans of Greek cuisine, vegetarians, and lovers of Greek wines.

With the arrival of warm weather, Mazi opens their lovely shaded terrace for your enjoyment.

Mazi
12-14 Hillgate Street
London W8 7SR

+44 (0)20 7229 3794

www.mazi.co.uk

Menu: around 32 GBP

content.title: The Columbia Road Flower Market: a Sunday outing

introduction.small: On a Sunday, come rain or shine, sleet or snow, come to Columbia Road for the flower power you need to colour your week.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Columbia Road Flower Market: a Sunday outing

paragraphs.text:
Head to the East End, close to Brick Lane, Old Spitalfields Market, and Shoreditch, where you can walk through a maze of stalls of flowers and plants on Columbia Road. Roses in the wildest colours full of heavenly scents, red peonies and yellow sunflowers, depending on the season, the street is full of different shapes and colours... and lots and lots of people (the only downside to this trip).

On either side of Columbia Road, you will find small art galleries, antique vintage-clothing stores as well as charming shops like Angela Flanders with its fantastic fragrances to choose from, not mentioning the numerous pubs and cafés where you will be delighted to rest before heading home.

If you need flowers any other day of the week, check out the flower market of New Covent Garden, open daily from 4:00 a.m. to 10:00 a.m.

Columbia Road Flower Market
Columbia Road
London E2 7RG

www.columbiaroad.info

content.title: Claridge's: enter the legend

introduction.small: A hotel with exceptional service and timeless elegance.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Claridge's: enter the legend

paragraphs.text:
At once an iconic building in Mayfair and an Art Deco temple, Claridge's is a legendary place that was once the refuge for European royalty during the Second World War. Its 203 rooms and suites, the most spacious in London, are designed with a timeless elegance.

Some have been decorated by leading fashion designers. Diane von Furstenberg, a veteran of the place, has spiced up the Third Floor Piano Suite with her contemporary signature. Other rooms had their decor inspired by The Great Gatsby, such as those entrusted to Viscount David Linley, nephew of Queen Elizabeth. In the late afternoon, after sightseeing and shopping, do not forget to take afternoon tea, with the delicious finger sandwiches, pastries, and scones for which only the English have the secret.

Behind its trendy reputation, Claridge's still cultivates old-world charm and service of quality.

Claridge's
Brook Street
London W1K 4HR

+44 (0)20 7629 8860

www.claridges.co.uk

Rooms: from 492 GBP

content.title: Hamleys: a place to become a child again

introduction.small: The realm of the little ones in the Kingdom of England.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hamleys: a place to become a child again

paragraphs.text:
Open for more than 250 years, Hamleys was long the largest toy store in the world.

While others have since surpassed it in size, it remains an immense paradise for children and a magical place for the parents and adults who have the luck of accompanying them here (or who find reasons to come on their own). More than 5 million people crowd into Hamleys each year.

Required stops on a London trip? Buckingham Palace, Big Ben and Hamleys! Taking up six storeys, from the basement to the 5th floor, you will find everything: dolls, games, stuffed animals, and super-hero figurines all have their own areas. You will have a hard time leaving empty-handed…

Hamleys
188-196 Regent Street
London W1B 5BT

+44 (0)371 704 1977

www.hamleys.com

content.title: Boundary Hotel: design made in Shoreditch

introduction.small: Sir Terence Conran invites you home to East London.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Boundary Hotel: design made in Shoreditch

paragraphs.text:
The Boundary Hotel of Sir Terence Conran is in an old renovated Victorian warehouse in Shoreditch.

On the first two floors, 12 rooms each pay tribute to a different illustrious interior designer, including Andrée Putman and Eileen Gray. The third and fourth floors have five original suites; four are duplexes designed by Sir Terence Conran himself, along with his wife and sister, through the furniture company Benchmark, of which he is the co-creator. Sir David Tang was entrusted with the decoration of the fifth suite according to Chinese inspiration. In the basement, the Boundary Restaurant & Bar offers a delicious and very original French menu. On the ground floor, the Albion Café serves breakfast all day and hearty British favourites such as fish and chips.

The Boundary features a roof garden where you can lunch and dinner throughout the year with a heated orangery. A must in London!

Boundary Hotel
2-4 Boundary Street
Shoreditch
London E2 7DD

+44 (0)20 7729 1051

www.theboundary.co.uk

Rooms: from 170 GBP

content.title: Dean Street Townhouse: all the charm you need

introduction.small: One of the prize addresses of the Soho House Group.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Dean Street Townhouse: all the charm you need

paragraphs.text:
With a fabulous location in the heart of Soho, Dean Street Townhouse is close to the best restaurants and London nightlife. This beautiful Georgian building, known for hosting artists and intellectuals in the 1930s, still radiates creative, smart, and inspiring energy.

The 39 rooms have names to describe their sizes: “Tiny”, measures 15 square metres, the cosier “Small” is a bit larger, and then there are the comfortable “Medium” and the “Bigger” suite, which is just over 40 square metres. An Edwardian style, both elegant and subtle, is to be found throughout. Bathrooms feature tropical showers and deep tubs, equipped with branded Cowshed products, present in all institutions of the group.

In some rooms, a bathtub is placed at the foot of the bed, as was the fashion of yesteryear. Do not miss the restaurant on the ground floor, with its worn wood floors, glass chandeliers, and magnificent retro wallpaper. So British!

Dean Street Townhouse
69-71 Dean Street
London W1D 3SE

+44 (0)207 7434 1775

www.deanstreettownhouse.com/hotel

Rooms: from 120 GBP

content.title: The Royal Albert Hall: let the show begin!

introduction.small: The most prestigious concert hall in London offers an exceptional programme.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Royal Albert Hall: let the show begin!

paragraphs.text:
The Royal Albert Hall was opened by Queen Victoria in March 1871 and named in honour of her late husband, Prince Albert. The most famous artistic establishment in London, it has room for 5,272 spectators.

While its breathtaking architecture and rich interiors make it an attraction in itself, the Royal Albert Hall owes a large part of its reputation to its fantastic programming. Host in the past to such legends as Richard Wagner, Arthur Rubinstein, the Beatles, and the Rolling Stones, the Hall also welcomed General de Gaulle for his famous speech of 15 November 1941.

The Royal Albert Hall is still today the favourite place of the greatest artists, offering exceptional theatre shows like Cirque du Soleil or the English National Ballet, and is even converted into the most unusual of tennis courts for the Champions Tennis tournament.

Royal Albert Hall
Kensington Gore
London SW7 2AP

+44 (0)20 7589 8212

www.royalalberthall.com

content.title: Liberty: British excellence

introduction.small: Throughout the world, these fabrics enchant. In London, the store amazes!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Liberty: British excellence

paragraphs.text:
Once upon a time, Arthur Lasenby Liberty, a man of delicate taste, drew sublime designs with floral motifs for cotton fabrics, to the delight of little girls and their mothers. In 1875, he opened his store on Regent Street and quickly offered his own clothing creations there.

Today, Liberty is a large Tudor-style department store that sells major brands and a place where all generations love to browse. From clothing, jewellery, and furniture to household linen and light fixtures, the most beautiful pieces have been selected and are presented in a breath-taking setting.

Many of Liberty's fabrics are still showcased, with regularly evolving new creations on offer. Check out the stationery department for portable keepsakes, such as small notebooks or colourful floral baubles, to bring home as gifts.

Liberty
214- 220 Regent Street (main entrance on Great Malborough Street)
London W1B 5AH

+44 (0)20 7734 1234

www.liberty.co.uk

content.title: Burger and Lobster: it's one or the other!

introduction.small: No need for a menu--they don't even have one. As they say: “We already have too many decisions to make in life, so let's keep it simple.”

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Burger and Lobster: it's one or the other!

paragraphs.text:
Dear vegetarians, this address is not for you. Burger and Lobster, as its name suggests, offers a very simple choice evident in its name: grilled lobster or a burger, made with marbled cuts of steak that come from Nebraska (tastier than British meats, according to the owners). The lobster is served on a large plate that includes a green salad, fries and the most amazing butter sauce for gentle dipping.

The young and old alike put on their plastic bib to enjoy this delicate and tasty dish.

Burger and Lobster has nine addresses in London: Mayfair, Soho, Farringdon, Bond Street, Bread Street, Knightsbridge, Oxford Circus, Old Bailey, and of course, Threadneedle Street.

Burger and Lobster
52 Threadneedle Street
London EC2R 8AR

+44 (0)20 7256 9755

www.burgerandlobster.com

Menu: around 27 GBP

content.title: Blakes Hotel: a home away from home

introduction.small: A feast for the eyes and a delightful evasion away from the world.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Blakes Hotel: a home away from home

paragraphs.text:
Blakes Hotel is known for being the first boutique hotel in the world. Designed by the famous Anouska Hempel, a New Zealand actress who became a famous interior designer.

The greyish black facade sets it apart from its red or white neighbours in South Kensington, also known as the French Quarter. Inside, the style is very plush, sometimes dark, always neat, elegant, and a touch masculine. The Gypsy Room, the Cardinal Suite, and the Dorian Grey Suite will all let you make the most of your stay in London.

Within the hotel there is even a small mews dating from the 18th century, composed of several rooms, from 25 to 35 sqm. You can make it your private residence with friends or family. The quality of service is as exceptional as the decor. You'll love the outdoor courtyard, where there is a delightful little glass greenhouse for taking breakfast or an evening drink.

Blakes Hotel
33 Roland Gardens
London SW7 3PF

+44 (0)20 7370 6701

www.blakeshotels.com

Rooms: from 250 GBP

content.title: The Palomar: one of the best restaurants in London

introduction.small: What's the first thing you should do when you are planning a trip to London? Reserve a table at the Palomar!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Palomar: one of the best restaurants in London

paragraphs.text:
“Fabulous! Extraordinary! Fantastic!”, are words that are often heard coming from the mouths of those who have just seen a great show. But here, even if one is in the theatre district, you will hear these superlatives from people coming out of the Palomar.

This restaurant, opened in 2014, can accommodate 50 people per service, including 16 who will have the privilege of dining on the zinc bar facing chef Tomer Amedi and his team. The flavours of southern Spain, northern Africa, and the Middle East make Palomar's dishes a trip for the senses.

A warm and festive atmosphere, a great staff, and excellent food prepared with passion will make your visit here one of your fondest memories of London. Add to that the restaurant's very reasonable prices and you'll understand why the Palomar is an address that some would like to keep to themselves.

The Palomar
34 Rupert Street
London W1D 6DN

+44 (0)7439 8777

www.thepalomar.co.uk/

Menu: around 21 GBP
